prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(2-1) line of Virgo galaxies with Vlsr=1000-2000km/s
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We devided the science goals because of their largely scattered positions and velocities. The coordinates and velocities are from Table 1 of Sofue et al. (2003b) except NGC 4303, whose parameters are from Koda et al. (2006). Other relevant parameters are shown in Table 1 of the science case.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Because the resolution of the NMA is much lower than that of ALMA, estimating the peak flux density using our NMA results will lead to a significant underestimation due to beam smearing effect. Thus, We expect the peak brightness temperature of T_CO(2-1)=10K, which is estimated from T_CO(1-0) of typical GMCs in the Milky Way with an assumption of CO(2-1)/CO(1-0) line ratio of 1 obtained by Oka et al. (1998). That is equivalent to 47 mJy/beam at our settings. Because GMCs in the galactic centers are crowded, it is possible that a significant fraction of the total flux is extended. If we assume that 50% of the flux of our targets are resolved out, the peak flux density covered by the 12-m array is estimated as 24 mJy/beam. In order to detect the peak emission with more than 10 sigma, and the emission at the rim of the nuclear region of our interest (r=5 arcsec: the same as the maximum angular resolution of our NMA data) with more than 5 sigma, we require the sensitivity of 1.4 mJy/beam (300 mK). We added the spectral settings for the CS(5-4) line that is a tracer of high-density gas (with a critical density of 3e-6/cc), in order to maximize the scientific output.

We expect the intrinsic velocity dispersion of molecular gas sigma_v ~ 10 km/s, based on sigma_v ~ 30 km/s of CO J=2-1 line in the central r < 400 pc of the Galaxy (Oka et al. 1998) and sigma_v ~ 7 km/s of CO J=2-1 line in the central r < 500 pc of a face-on galaxy NGC 628 (Wilson et al. 2011), assuming sigma_v in the nucleus is larger than that of outer regions. Thus we adopt a velocity resolution of dv = 10.5 km/s, which is same as that of our NMA data. Because maximum velocity widths of our targets range from 180 to 480 km/s and we need the velocity resolution of 10.5 km/s in Band 6, we use the FDM correlator mode of 1875 MHz bandwidth and 976.563 kHz channel spacing for dual polarization.

We require to obtain the dynamical mass distributions of the galactic centerss at a spatial resolution of 25 pc (0.33 arcsec), which is eight times higher than our NMA data and enough to resolve the massive cores. The largest angular scale of interest is 5 arcsec, which is the same as the lowest angular resolution of our NMA data. They can be achieved with the 12-m array only.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(2-1) line of NGC 4303 & NGC 4536
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Because these galaxies are 10 degrees or more apart from other targets, we divided the science goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Because the resolution of the NMA is much lower than that of ALMA, estimating the peak flux density using our NMA results will lead to a significant underestimation due to beam smearing effect. We expect the intrinsic velocity dispersion of molecular gas sigma_v ~ 10 km/s, based on sigma_v ~ 30 km/s of CO J=2-1 line in the central r < 400 pc of the Galaxy (Oka et al. 1998) and sigma_v ~ 7 km/s of CO J=2-1 line in the central r < 500 pc of a face-on galaxy NGC 628 (Wilson et al. 2011), assuming sigma_v in the nucleus is larger than that of outer regions. Thus we adopt a velocity resolution of dv = 10.5 km/s, which is same as that of our NMA data. Because maximum velocity widths of our targets range from 180 to 480 km/s and we need the velocity resolution of 10.5 km/s in Band 6, we use the FDM correlator mode of 1875 MHz bandwidth and 976.563 kHz channel spacing for dual polarization.

The largest angular scale of interest is 5 arcsec, which is the same as the lowest angular resolution of our NMA data. They can be achieved with the 12-m array only.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(2-1) line of Virgo galaxies with Vlsr > 2000 km/s
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Because the velocities of these galaxies are apart from other targets, we divided the science goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Because the resolution of the NMA is much lower than that of ALMA, estimating the peak flux density using our NMA results will lead to a significant underestimation due to beam smearing effect. Thus, We expect the peak brightness temperature of T_CO(2-1)=10K, which is estimated from T_CO(1-0) of typical GMCs in the Milky Way with an assumption of CO(2-1)/CO(1-0) line ratio of 1 obtained by Oka et al. (1998). That is equivalent to 47 mJy/beam at our settings. Because GMCs in the galactic centers are crowded, it is possible that a significant fraction of the total flux is extended. If we assume that 50% of the flux of our targets are resolved out, the peak flux density covered by the 12-m array is estimated as 24 mJy/beam. We expect the intrinsic velocity dispersion of molecular gas sigma_v ~ 10 km/s, based on sigma_v ~ 30 km/s of CO J=2-1 line in the central r < 400 pc of the Galaxy (Oka et al. 1998) and sigma_v ~ 7 km/s of CO J=2-1 line in the central r < 500 pc of a face-on galaxy NGC 628 (Wilson et al. 2011), assuming sigma_v in the nucleus is larger than that of outer regions. Thus we adopt a velocity resolution of dv = 10.5 km/s, which is same as that of our NMA data. Because maximum velocity widths of our targets range from 180 to 480 km/s and we need the velocity resolution of 10.5 km/s in Band 6, we use the FDM correlator mode of 1875 MHz bandwidth and 976.563 kHz channel spacing for dual polarization.

We require to obtain the dynamical mass distributions of the galactic centerss at a spatial resolution of 25 pc (0.33 arcsec), which is eight times higher than our NMA data and enough to resolve the massive cores. The largest angular scale of interest is 5 arcsec, which is the same as the lowest angular resolution of our NMA data. They can be achieved with the 12-m array only.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(2-1) line of Virgo galaxies with Vlsr less than 1000km/s
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We devided the science goals because of their largely scattered positions and velocities. The coordinates and velocities are from Table 1 of Sofue et al. (2003b). Other relevant parameters are shown in Table 1 of the science case.

(1998). That is equivalent to 47 mJy/beam at our settings. Because GMCs in the galactic centers are crowded, it is possible that a significant fraction of the total flux is extended. The largest angular scale of interest is 5 arcsec, which is the same as the lowest angular resolution of our NMA data. They can be achieved with the 12-m array only.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO mapping observations toward the center of 12 Virgo cluster spiral galaxies. This project aims at obtaining detailed mass distributions between central black holes (BHs) and bulges, which is indispensable to reveal their nature and co-evolution. This is the natural extension of our NMA survey of the Virgo spirals in the CO line. The Virgo cluster galaxies are unique for their common and well-determined Cepheid distance, so that their data can be analyzed statistically, and measured quantities are reliable, as well as the wealth of archival data. CO J=2-1 observations with the ALMA is the best suitable to obtain much higher resolution (0.33"= 25 pc) velocity field than the NMA. This dataset, combined with our iteration method for deriving accurate rotation curves, will clarify the nuclear gravitational potential deeply coupled to the formation and evolution of central BHs. Together with our previous results, the gravitational potential or dynamical mass distribution can be derived continuously from bulges to nuclei. We will examine if the dark matter cusp suggested by numerical simulations indeed exists, by obtaining the high-resolution central mass-to-luminosity ratio.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Division of Liberal Arts, Kogakuin University
Astronomy Program, New York at Stony Brook, State University of
